div.p: On finishing the Lady from the Sea I said to myself “I must write to Mr Wells to tell him how immensely the book improves, and how extremely well done + interesting (in the very sense I wanted) it seems to me” - When your letter came, I left Leeds for Scotland, and then your gift of books came --. And then, instead of writing this rider to my previous letter, I gave what little time my work and the old lady I was staying with, left me, not to letter writing but to reading first your paper from Mind and then your enchanting novel. Dear Mr Wells, you are a great, great deal too modest. I have now read two thirds of “Love + Mr Lewisham” and I must permit myself to say that if you include it in what you say of yourself, you are silly. It is a very fine, earnest, mature book - mature I mean not merely in the depth of its humanity and of its philosophical sweep of view (for one feels somehow the whole time that Lewisham is but a minute scrap of the great Will to Exist) but mature also in the execution: the slightness of what is actually given, the wealth of what one feels behind the construction, emphasis, carrying the subject + [dropping] it - Quite apart from the contents it seems to me admirable. It has that admirable quality of slightness, of earnestness, which so rare in English novels, the very quality I alluded to when I said that to treat subjects like the Time Machine one should have the handling of men like Anatole France. And the earlier part of the book is really very beautiful: the love making of these people, with its charming reticence, has got an extraordinary quality of impersonal passion; not the love of Mr so + so + Miss such a one, but just love in the abstract, the love of all young creatures, akin the powers which make [sap rise] + buds swell; + with the pathos of the fatal [?] of the [Will]. It is this which gives it dignity, [charmingly] lifting it far above the chronicling of any sort of individual small [?]. Thank you for the great pleasure you have given + will give me. I should like to know, from you, which of your books are most akin to this one, so as to get them for my solitary winter evening’s reading.

I should like to send you something of mine in return. Looking around at my far too voluminous works, I fear most of them would strike you as literature for aesthetes or rich dilettantes, though as a fact that is what I hate most. But I will find something, merely for the pleasure of being on your shelves. My serious work nowadays us psychology; + some day you shall have a specimen. But I think I will send you some of my old morality books. Some day I hope to have my say about serious matters; when I shall know my own mind better, have got over the terror of conflicting + fad, which paralyse me considerably. The Mind paper is very interesting; + still more so your pamphlet on [founding/forming] the future, which I have just read -
The porter is calling me, so I break off.

I only want to suggest 1st. in estimating the possibilities of any future moral code, aren’t we apt to forget that we virtually have always had two, one for the rule + one for the exception, one preached, the other acted on.

2d that the old theology was perfectly correct in its anthropocentric views. We are the centre of the universe for all our own practical purposes; + we are so more than they thought, since the universe we know about is the universe conceived by us, constructed by us with faculties produced + limited by our human requirements. In fact are the Comtistes, [?] us they are, not on the whole, nearer the truth than those who (like you, if I judge by the end of Anticipation) would give us the Universal Will, or the Will to Live, as a divinity. Man is his own divinity; he has to fight that old Will to Live (+ Die!) with its own weapons. I see the universe rather as a kind of manichean dualism, only if it is the [?]=man who has created good, spirit out of the mere indifferent thing, matter, force, furnished by the original creator.
I shall be in the North another ten days, + after a brief time in Surrey + at Oxford, shall return to Italy in September. My address till Sept. 15 will be Grosvenor Crescent Club
Please remember me very warmly to Mrs Wells.
Thanks again for all the pleasure you have given me. I finished Mr Lewisham last night; it is fine, moving, manly, [?] + philosophic.
